Matters Arising18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Unsupervised pretraining in biological neural networks (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Unsupervised pretraining in biological neural networks

During visual learning, neural plasticity is driven by unsupervised learning in mice.

  • Lin Zhong
  • Scott Baptista
  • Marius Pachitariu
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Complete computational design of high-efficiency Kemp elimination enzymes (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Complete computational design of high-efficiency Kemp elimination enzymes

We present a computational approach to the design of high-efficiency enzymes with catalytic parameters comparable to natural enzymes, enabling programming of stable, high-efficiency, new-to-nature Kemp elimination enzymes through minimal experimental effort.

  • Dina Listov
  • Eva Vos
  • Sarel J. Fleishman
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Optical nonlinearities in excess of 500 through sublattice reconstruction (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Optical nonlinearities in excess of 500 through sublattice reconstruction

A strategy for engineering photon-avalanche nanoparticles is proposed such that they exhibit an unprecedentedly strong nonlinear optical response and their emissions scale by more than 500th power of the pump intensity.

  • Jiaye Chen
  • Chang Liu
  • Xiaogang Liu
Article18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Bimodal centromeres in pentaploid dogroses shed light on their unique meiosis (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Bimodal centromeres in pentaploid dogroses shed light on their unique meiosis

Insights into the dogrose genome and centromeres explain their ability to achieve stable sexual reproduction.

  • V. Herklotz
  • M. Zhang
  • C. M. Ritz
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Kupffer cell programming by maternal obesity triggers fatty liver disease (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Kupffer cell programming by maternal obesity triggers fatty liver disease

In a mouse model, maternal obesity during pregnancy can lead to fatty liver disease in the offspring, driven by aberrant developmental programming of Kuppfer cells.

  • Hao Huang
  • Nora R. Balzer
  • Elvira Mass
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Allosteric modulation and biased signalling at free fatty acid receptor 2 (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Allosteric modulation and biased signalling at free fatty acid receptor 2

Structural, pharmacological and computational studies reveal how different classes of positive allosteric modulators bind to distinct allosteric sites and use noncanonical mechanisms to activate the free-fatty acid receptor FFA2.

  • Xuan Zhang
  • Abdul-Akim Guseinov
  • Cheng Zhang
Article18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Machine-learning design of ductile FeNiCoAlTa alloys with high strength (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Machine-learning design of ductile FeNiCoAlTa alloys with high strength

A new group of multi-principal-element alloys, designed through machine learning and extreme microstructural heterogeneities, achieve high strength (1.8-GPa yield strength) and ductility (25% uniform elongation) at room temperature.

  • Yasir Sohail
  • Chongle Zhang
  • En Ma
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Impacts of climate change on global agriculture accounting for adaptation (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Impacts of climate change on global agriculture accounting for adaptation

Analysis of data on six stable crops, capturing two-thirds of global crop calories, allows estimation of agricultural impacts and the potential of global producer adaptations to reduce output losses owing to climate change.

  • Andrew Hultgren
  • Tamma Carleton
  • Jiacan Yuan
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Gut inflammation promotes microbiota-specific CD4 T cell-mediated neuroinflammation (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Gut inflammation promotes microbiota-specific CD4 T cell-mediated neuroinflammation

Dysregulated CD4 T cells that recognize gut commensal antigens are able to infiltrate the central nervous systems and are re-stimulated by host proteins, resulting in neuroinflammation.

  • Zachary White
  • Ivan Cabrera
  • Teruyuki Sano
Article18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Targeting de novo purine biosynthesis for tuberculosis treatment (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Targeting de novo purine biosynthesis for tuberculosis treatment

The validation of inhibitors targeting PurF, a novel drug target for tuberculosis drug discovery, is described.

  • Dirk A. Lamprecht
  • Richard J. Wall
  • Anil Koul
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Morphodynamics of human early brain organoid development (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Morphodynamics of human early brain organoid development

Human brain morphodynamics are explored using organoids.

  • Akanksha Jain
  • Gilles Gut
  • Barbara Treutlein
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Bioinspired capillary force-driven super-adhesive filter (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Bioinspired capillary force-driven super-adhesive filter

Stable coating of filters with a thin liquid layer enhances adhesion of airborne particulates while maintaining high air permeability, resulting in longer lifetimes and higher efficiency of these filters.

  • Junyong Park
  • Chan Sik Moon
  • Sanghyuk Wooh
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Bogong moths use a stellar compass for long-distance navigation at night (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Bogong moths use a stellar compass for long-distance navigation at night

Every spring, Bogong moths use the starry night sky as a compass to navigate up to 1,000 km towards their alpine migratory goal.

  • David Dreyer
  • Andrea Adden
  • Eric Warrant
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Major expansion in the human niche preceded out of Africa dispersal (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Major expansion in the human niche preceded out of Africa dispersal

Analysis of species distribution models in a pan-African database comprising chronometrically dated archaeological sites over the past 120,000 years shows major expansion in the human niche from 70 ka, driven by adaptation to diverse habitats.

  • Emily Y. Hallett
  • Michela Leonardi
  • Eleanor M. L. Scerri
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: In vivo mapping of mutagenesis sensitivity of human enhancers (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
In vivo mapping of mutagenesis sensitivity of human enhancers

Human enhancers contain a high density of sequence features that are required for their normal in vivo function.

  • Michael Kosicki
  • Boyang Zhang
  • Len A. Pennacchio
Article18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Single-cell transcriptomic and chromatin dynamics of the human brain in PTSD (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Single-cell transcriptomic and chromatin dynamics of the human brain in PTSD

A comprehensive analysis of the cell-specific molecular regulatory mechanisms underlying post-traumatic stress disorder in the human prefrontal cortex.

  • Ahyeon Hwang
  • Mario Skarica
  • Matthew J. Girgenti
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025

elements.title: Vertically stacked monolithic perovskite colour photodetectors (Nature - research articles)
elements.contents:
Vertically stacked monolithic perovskite colour photodetectors

A colour sensor array based on multilayer monolithically stacked lead halide perovskite thin-film photodetectors achieves higher quantum efficiency and superior colour accuracy compared to conventional filter-based image sensors.

  • Sergey Tsarev
  • Daria Proniakova
  • Maksym V. Kovalenko
ArticleOpen Access18 Jun 2025
